rev.diff:
Line 28: Line 28:
==Viacom==
==Viacom==
â
[[Image:Viacom logo.svg|185px|Viacom logo|thumb|right]]
 
Looking for a new business venture, he set his sights on [[Viacom|Viacom International]], a company which he had already been buying stock in as an investment and was a spin-off of [[CBS]] in 1971 after the [[Federal Communications Commission|FCC]] ruled that [[television network]]s could not [[Television syndication|syndicate]] programs they produced. Viacom syndicated most of CBS's programs, but also made a lot of money from syndicating other programs, including most of [[Carsey-Werner Productions]]' shows (''[[The Cosby Show]]'', ''[[Roseanne (TV series)|Roseanne]]'', and ''[[A Different World (TV series)|A Different World]]''), as well as syndicating shows for other companies ([[Columbia Pictures Television]]'s ''[[All in the Family]]'' was one notable example), and cable channels ([[Nickelodeon (TV channel)|Nickelodeon]]'s ''[[Double Dare (1986 game show)|Double Dare]]'' and ''[[Finders Keepers (1987 TV series)|Finders Keepers]]'' (co-syndicated with [[Fox Television Stations]]) were two examples).
Looking for a new business venture, he set his sights on [[Viacom|Viacom International]], a company which he had already been buying stock in as an investment and was a spin-off of [[CBS]] in 1971 after the [[Federal Communications Commission|FCC]] ruled that [[television network]]s could not [[Television syndication|syndicate]] programs they produced. Viacom syndicated most of CBS's programs, but also made a lot of money from syndicating other programs, including most of [[Carsey-Werner Productions]]' shows (''[[The Cosby Show]]'', ''[[Roseanne (TV series)|Roseanne]]'', and ''[[A Different World (TV series)|A Different World]]''), as well as syndicating shows for other companies ([[Columbia Pictures Television]]'s ''[[All in the Family]]'' was one notable example), and cable channels ([[Nickelodeon (TV channel)|Nickelodeon]]'s ''[[Double Dare (1986 game show)|Double Dare]]'' and ''[[Finders Keepers (1987 TV series)|Finders Keepers]]'' (co-syndicated with [[Fox Television Stations]]) were two examples).
Line 47: Line 46:
==CBS==
==CBS==
â
[[Image:CBS Corporation.png|thumb|right]]
 
One of Redstone's largest acquisitions came in the form of Viacom's former parent, CBS. Former Viacom President & COO [[Mel Karmazin]] (who was then the President of CBS) proposed a merger to Redstone on favorable terms and after the merger completed in 2000, Viacom had some of the most diversified businesses imaginable. Viacom had assets in the form of broadcast networks (CBS and [[UPN]]), [[cable television]] networks (MTV, Nickelodeon, [[MTV2]], [[Comedy Central]], [[Black Entertainment Television|BET]], [[Nick at Nite]], [[Noggin (TV channel)|Noggin]]/[[The N]], [[TV Land]], [[Country Music Television|CMT]], and [[Spike TV]]), [[pay television]] ([[Showtime]] and [[The Movie Channel]]), [[Radio programming|radio]] ([[Infinity Broadcasting]], which produced the immensely popular [[Howard Stern]]' [[Talk radio|radio show]]s), [[outdoor advertising]], motion pictures ([[Paramount Pictures]]), and [[television production]] ([[Spelling Entertainment]], [[Paramount Television]], and [[Big Ticket Entertainment]]), and [[King World Productions]] (a syndication unit, which notably syndicates the runaway daytime hit, ''[[The Oprah Winfrey Show]]'', as well as ''[[Dr. Phil (TV series)|Dr. Phil]]'', ''[[Wheel of Fortune (American game show)|Wheel of Fortune]]'', and ''[[Jeopardy!]]''), among others.
One of Redstone's largest acquisitions came in the form of Viacom's former parent, CBS. Former Viacom President & COO [[Mel Karmazin]] (who was then the President of CBS) proposed a merger to Redstone on favorable terms and after the merger completed in 2000, Viacom had some of the most diversified businesses imaginable. Viacom had assets in the form of broadcast networks (CBS and [[UPN]]), [[cable television]] networks (MTV, Nickelodeon, [[MTV2]], [[Comedy Central]], [[Black Entertainment Television|BET]], [[Nick at Nite]], [[Noggin (TV channel)|Noggin]]/[[The N]], [[TV Land]], [[Country Music Television|CMT]], and [[Spike TV]]), [[pay television]] ([[Showtime]] and [[The Movie Channel]]), [[Radio programming|radio]] ([[Infinity Broadcasting]], which produced the immensely popular [[Howard Stern]]' [[Talk radio|radio show]]s), [[outdoor advertising]], motion pictures ([[Paramount Pictures]]), and [[television production]] ([[Spelling Entertainment]], [[Paramount Television]], and [[Big Ticket Entertainment]]), and [[King World Productions]] (a syndication unit, which notably syndicates the runaway daytime hit, ''[[The Oprah Winfrey Show]]'', as well as ''[[Dr. Phil (TV series)|Dr. Phil]]'', ''[[Wheel of Fortune (American game show)|Wheel of Fortune]]'', and ''[[Jeopardy!]]''), among others.
Line 66: Line 64:
==Holdings==
==Holdings==
â
[[Image:Midway logo.png|300px|thumb|right]]
 
Currently, Redstone owns over seventy percent of the [[voting stock]] of Viacom, which, in actuality, is a not wholly-owned subsidiary of [[National Amusements]], which is his privately held, family-owned company. CBS Corporation, likewise, is controlled by Redstone through National Amusements. Redstone also owns over eighty-nine percent of [[Midway Games]], both individually and through National Amusements.
Currently, Redstone owns over seventy percent of the [[voting stock]] of Viacom, which, in actuality, is a not wholly-owned subsidiary of [[National Amusements]], which is his privately held, family-owned company. CBS Corporation, likewise, is controlled by Redstone through National Amusements. Redstone also owns over eighty-nine percent of [[Midway Games]], both individually and through National Amusements.
